name: Annual Pavement Management
description: The Town is responsible for maintaining 240 miles of municipal streets with an annual resurfacing contract providing for most pavement maintenance needs. Street mileage is growing annually with ongoing development. A recent survey of our streets revealed that deferred maintenance needs to be addressed. This ongoing program focuses on deficiencies in pavement conditions throughout Apex and addresses issues, such as potholes, alligator cracking, and rutting, to provide a safe and reliable transportation system. This program also includes lower cost pavement preservation tools to extend pavement life cycle and reduce long term resurfacing costs while ensuring curb ramps on all resurfacing projects comply with state and federal mandates. Powell Bill funding is allocated from the State for road maintenance, but current and future resurfacing costs continue to exceed Powell Bill allocations, requiring General Fund revenues to be allocated.
funding_source: Anticipated Powell Bill Funding: $17,000,000, Anticipated Town Funding: $7,375,000

name: Apex Peakway at Tingen Road Intersection Improvements
description: This project adds left turn lanes and a traffic signal with signalized crosswalks at the intersection of Apex Peakway and Tingen Road to accommodate increased traffic from nearby development including Grace Christian School, Veridea, and the Apex Peakway bridge opening. Without turn lanes and a traffic signal, this intersection during peak hours may experience high levels of congestion and delays.

name: Apex Peakway North Widening
description: This project widens the existing Apex Peakway from a two-lane median-divided road to a four-lane median-divided road. Peak hour traffic exceeds the existing roadway’s capacity, so this widening will reduce queue lengths and delays. Without it, the road will continue to cause longer delays, make access difficult for commuters and emergency vehicles, cause more drivers to divert to other local routes, and increase congestion elsewhere.
funding_source: Anticipated Bond Funding: $9,000,000, Anticipated Town Funding: $4,100,000

name: Apex Peakway Southwest Widening
description: This project widens 1600’ of the existing Apex Peakway from a two-lane road to a four-lane median-divided road between Padstone Drive and James Street. Peak hour traffic will exceed existing roadway capacity within five years. In addition to other projects, this project will help complete a contiguous four-lane section from Towhee Drive to Tingen Road. Without it, the road will continue to cause longer delays making access difficult for commuters and emergency vehicles.

name: Center Street RR Crossing Improvements
description: This project improves and expands the railroad crossing surface to accommodate a sidewalk crossing. This project extends the sidewalk on the south side of Center Street to complete a short gap from the Depot frontage across the tracks to Elm Street. This project also upgrades to four-quadrant gates and the associated railroad equipment upgrades. This project 13 prevents pedestrians from being forced onto the roadway and may create a quiet zone at this crossing due to the safety enhancements
funding_source: Anticipated Bond Funding: $850,000, Anticipated Town Funding: $500,000

name: Chatham Street RR Crossing Improvements
description: This project improves and expands the railroad crossing surface to accommodate a sidewalk crossing. This project extends the sidewalk on the north side of Chatham Street to the east corner of Elm Street with a crosswalk to the south side of Chatham Street where the sidewalk connects today. This project also upgrades to four-quadrant gates and the associated railroad equipment upgrades. This project prevents pedestrians from being forced onto the roadway and may create a quiet zone at this crossing due to the safety enhancements.
funding_source: Anticipated Bond Funding: $850,000, Anticipated Town Funding: $500,000

name: Center & Chatham St Sidewalk Phase 2
description: This project completes additional sidewalk gaps across the Center Street and Chatham Street railroad crossings where prior projects upgraded the crossings and completed the sidewalk gaps on one side of each road. This project includes sidewalk along the north side of Center Street from N. Salem Street to N. Mason Street and sidewalk along the south side of Chatham Street from S. Salem Street to S. Elm Street and from N. Mason Street to the cul-de-sac and existing sidewalk in front of Clairmont Park. The project serves Safe Routes to School needs for Apex Middle School.

name: Davis Dr at Salem Church Rd Realignment
description: This project realigns 1000' of Davis Drive north of Jenks Road to improve the horizontal curvature and widens that section of road to 4-lane divided. This project also widens Salem Church Road across the CSX tracks to a 3-lane section and installs new gates and lights. This intersection would have a traffic signal and railroad gate arms installed, and this intersection would shift west, away from the CSX railroad freight line, allowing vehicles to stack beyond the tracks. This project alleviates Salem Church Road needing to convert to right in-right out and alleviates safety concerns for the following issues: no left turn on Davis Drive backing up traffic southbound, no space for a traffic signal or gate arms to warn of an approaching train, and limited visibility around the curve on Davis Drive.
funding_source: General Fund / Capital Outlay, General Obligation Bonds

name: Downtown Projects: Commerce Street & Seaboard Street Improvements
description: This project funds the right-of-way and construction costs for the Commerce Street and Seaboard Street improvement projects. Improving these spaces is a "Top 10" priority in the Downtown Plan. These plans are based on schematic designs approved by Town Council in 2021 and design plans presented in 2022 prior to acquisition and final design.

name: GoApex New Bus Stop Installations
description: The Apex Transit Prioritization Study, accepted by Town Council in September of 2025, recommends improving and expanding local transit service. This includes changes to GoApex Route 1 routing, as well as two new local routes. This project includes costs for consultant-led design, right of way, and construction of approximately 30 new bus stops (~5 for Route 1, ~20 for Route 2, and ~5 for Route 3). This project will ensure new bus stops meet Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Public Right-of-Way Accessibility Guidelines (PROWAG) standards in accordance with the Apex Bus Stop Improvement Policy.
funding_source: Anticipated Grant Funding: $455,000, Anticipated Town Funding: $245,000

name: GPS Emergency Vehicle Preemption
description: This project installs GPS emergency vehicle preemption at 10 traffic signals each year, which allows emergency vehicles to interrupt normal traffic signal timing during an emergency. This project prioritizes major corridors (NC 55, Salem Street, Center Street, Ten Ten Road, Apex Peakway, etc.) and various signals adjacent to those major corridors.

name: Jessie Drive Phase 2
description: This project provides a contiguous major thoroughfare route between Ten Ten Road and NC 55 south of US 1 by completing a 4-lane divided missing gap in Jessie Drive between Production Drive and the Jessie Commons development project boundary. This assumes private development will make the connection to the NC 55 stubbing east of Middle Creek. This road would serve adjacent land development, including industrial and commercial areas. If there were a major closure or delay on NC 55 or Ten Ten Road, it would provide an east-west detour.

name: Olive Chapel Rd at Apex BBQ Rd Improvements
description: This project addresses traffic congestion and reduces potential crashes at the intersection of Olive Chapel Road and Apex Barbecue Road by adding a 150-foot westbound left turn lane, 6-foot paved shoulders allowing for future bike lanes, rumble strips along the edge lines, a wider eastbound right-turn radius, and a wood-pole traffic signal on Olive Chapel Road at Apex Barbecue Road. This project completes a sidewalk gap with 500’ of 10-foot side path eastward along the north side of Olive Chapel Road.
funding_source: Designated Capital Funds, Grants, General Fund / Capital Outlay

name: Richardson Road at Core Banks Street Traffic Signal
description: This project adds a traffic signal with signalized crosswalks at the intersection of Richardson Road at Core Banks Street to accommodate increased traffic from nearby development and address pedestrian safety inquiries. This project revises existing markings and pedestrian landings along with a metal strain pole traffic signal that would be maintained by the Town. Without a traffic signal, the intersection will experience longer delays as traffic continues to increase and pedestrians will not have protected crossings across Richardson Road to access mixed use development on both sides of the road.

name: S-line Mobility Hub
description: In partnership with the Town, NC Department of Transportation completed the Apex S-Line Mobility Hub Plan in 2025, which recommended the E. Moore Street public parking area to serve as a future multi-modal transportation mobility hub, including bus and possible rail. The plan recommends an initial phase to address bus transportation and future phases to address potential rail transportation. This project aligns with the draft 2035 Wake Transit Plan, which includes multiple new regional bus routes serving Apex; the Apex Transit Prioritization Study, which includes modifying GoApex Route 1 and adding two new local routes that connect downtown; and the Downtown Plan, which proposed a mobility hub at the corner of NC 55 and S. Salem Street. Delaying this project could impact the future transit routes and the opportunity of connecting in a central location in downtown Apex.
funding_source: Anticipated Grant Funding: $1,495,000, Anticipated Town Funding: $805,000

name: South Salem St Bicycle Connection
description: This project includes sharrows (road markings that indicate a shared environment for bicycles and vehicles) along Salem Street from Apex Peakway to Hunter Street and bike lanes along South Salem Street from Pleasant Park to Apex Peakway. This project was the second highest priority identified in Bike Apex: The Comprehensive Bicycle Plan.

name: Tingen Road Pedestrian Tunnel
description: This project constructs a bicycle and pedestrian tunnel under the railroad crossing of Tingen Road, realigns Tingen Road at Justice Heights Street, and provides a greenway connection between Salem Street and James Street. The Apex Peakway Southwest Connector project will close the current at-grade railroad crossing. This tunnel and greenway connection will provide safe crossings of the Tingen Road railroad tracks and improve access to downtown Apex, multi-family residential developments, multiple churches, and Apex Elementary School.

name: Traffic Signal System: Apex-Holly Springs-Fuquay-Varina Partnership
description: This project proposes an annual traffic signal system operation and maintenance agreement with the Town of Holly Springs and the Town of Fuquay-Varina. This regional partnership opportunity was identified in the Western Wake Traffic Signal System Integration Study. The Town of Apex has limited traffic signal maintenance responsibilities in a few locations, but as new signals are added to Town maintained roads and Town-maintained mileage and pedestrian facilities expand, the Town's responsibility along with potential safety and service benefits will continue to increase.

name: Wayfinding Signage
description: This project fabricates and installs Wayfinding signage throughout Town. Sign types include parking directional, vehicular directional, pedestrian directional, destination identification, gateway signage, and bicycle signage. This project was identified in the Downtown Plan and Parking Study and as an extension of the Community Branding Study. The Wayfinding Signage Program provides consistent and attractive information to help residents and visitors discover and navigate to key destinations in Town.

name: Wimberly Road Sidewalk
description: This project adds a sidewalk along the west side of Wimberly Road from Green Level West Road to Dorset Grove Road and a sidewalk along the east side of Wimberly Road from Lauder Lane to Burlap Drive. These sidewalks have been identified as a need by the Lake Castleberry subdivision and fee-in-lieu of sidewalk along Wimberly Road was provided by the developer.

name: Beaver Creek Greenway Extension
description: This project extends the Beaver Creek Greenway within Jaycee Park to the NC 55 Right of Way. During the NC 55 widening, the Town will cost share with NCDOT to extend the greenway under NC 55 with a grade separated crossing. This project also extends the 10' asphalt trail, including boardwalk and bridge sections, within the Nature Park to Richardson Road, providing connections to Bella Casa, Arcadia Ridge/West, and Buckhorn Preserve. Additionally, the Beaver Creek Greenway will extend west of Richardson Road on the south side of Beaver Creek along the southern edge of Army Corps of Engineers Jordan Lake land to the American Tobacco Trail north of the New Hill-Olive Chapel Road Wake County trailhead.
funding_source: General Fund / Capital Outlay, Designated Capital Funds, General Obligation Bond

name: Beaver Creek Greenway Renovation
description: This project renovates the Beaver Creek Greenway from Townside Drive to Kelly Road Park. This segment is heavily traveled by residents and experiences regular flooding from the Lawrence Prong and Beaver Creek waterways. Planning and engineering efforts would evaluate relocating the damaged infrastructure, realigning the trail, or conducting stream restoration, whichever is deemed acceptable to the Army Corp and FEMA as much of the trail is located within the floodplain and more restricted floodway. Renovations could reduce the need to close Beaver Creek during times of flooding.

name: Big Branch Greenway
description: This project completes the Big Branch Greenway corridor from James Street south to US 1. This 10' asphalt trail will provide connectivity to transit routes and side paths that extend to S. Salem Street along Tingen Road. It will also provide connectivity to Irongate, Lexington, Bradley Terrace, Perry Farms, other subdivisions, Apex Elementary School, and potentially Veridea Parkway after coordinating with the Grace Christian School project.

name: Community Park Trail Widening (Swift Creek Greenway)
description: This project widens the trail from eight feet to at least twelve feet. During widening, this project will create swales to address erosion and stormwater, increase the radius of sharp curves where possible, and lessen steep slopes or provide accessible landings. This project also preserves trees along the corridor, establishes shoulders, reinstalls or replaces memorial benches, and upgrades amenities to Town standards.

name: Environmental Education Center
description: This project designs and develops a +6,000-square-foot facility at the Apex Nature Park. The initial one-story design focuses on creating space for nature and environmental education, upfitting the existing shelter and restroom, and supporting amphitheater programming. This plan includes staff offices/workstations, a reception/information desk, exhibit space, adaptive classroom/gathering spaces, a catering kitchen, restrooms, and a conference room.

name: Hunter Street Park Renovation
description: This project replaces the Hunter Street Park turf field, which was installed in 2016. This field has experienced heavy usage and is beginning to show signs of wear. A new all-weather field is expected to last about ten years. This renovation increases paved surfaces and adds accessible visitor areas. This project also installs a retaining wall and slope stabilization to reduce erosion on the field surface and address stormwater concerns.

name: Jaycee Park Expansion
description: This project develops the west side of Jaycee Park adjacent to the Apex Peakway. Plans include an open play field, shelter with restroom, hillside playground, adaptive pickleball/tennis court, and additional parking. This expansion will connect to the Beaver Creek Greenway and existing Jaycee Park amenities.

name: KidsTowne Playground Renovation
description: This project replaces the KidsTowne Playground equipment, improves the surfacing, and adds a secondary rental shelter. This treated lumber, community-built playground is 24 years old, so the structure’s life is limited despite routine maintenance and component replacements. Renovations with long-lasting composite or metal components will increase this facility's longevity for another 20+ years and allow for a more accessible play facility to be constructed. Poured-in-place surfacing increases its accessibility and longevity and will reduce the time and replacement costs for mulch safety surfacing. The highly used shelter is often not available for public use due to rentals, so adding a larger secondary rental shelter would provide additional protected space for resident use.

name: Middle Creek Greenway
description: This project extends the bike and pedestrian facilities north of Jessie Drive to a signalized crossing of Ten Ten Road at Reliance Avenue. This greenway will ultimately connect to Swift Creek Greenway at Regency Park in the Town of Cary. This project connects six subdivisions, two schools, downtown Holly Springs, Pinnacle Park, Apex Commerce Center and Meridian at Ten Ten Apartments, and other commercial and office spaces.
funding_source: General Fund / Capital Outlay, General Obligation Bonds

name: Nature Park Operations & Maintenance Building
description: This project replaces the current Operations and Maintenance Building with a two story 30,000-square-foot office with a warehouse and sign shop and adds a two acre yard with staff parking to Town owned property on the eastern side of Evans Road.
funding_source: General Fund / Capital Outlay, Installment Purchase / Capital Lease

name: Reedy Branch Greenway
description: This project completes a greenway gap between the American Tobacco Trail and Kelly Road by extending the 10' asphalt Reedy Branch Greenway from Kelly Road to Goliath Lane. From the existing greenway at Goliath Lane, the proposed greenway runs east along the north side of Reedy Branch before crossing to the south side of the creek and continuing east to Kelly Road. A mid-block crossing proposed at Kelly Road would connect to the existing side path on the east side of the road. Neighborhood connections are proposed at Rothwood Way, Homestead Park Drive, Evening Star Drive, and Windy Creek Lane. This project provides connectivity to transit stops, Abbington, Stratford at Abbington, Sweetwater, Homestead Park, Creekside, and other connected subdivisions, schools, commercial spaces, and office spaces.
funding_source: General Fund / Capital Outlay, Designated Capital Funds

name: Seymour Athletic Fields and Nature Park Parking Lot Expansion and Turf Renovation
description: This project adds about 50 parking spaces near the Seymour Athletic Fields upon demolition of the current Operations and Maintenance building and yard. The project also renovates the existing synthetic turf fields and addresses drainage issues.

name: Street Hockey & Inclusive Playground
description: This project replaces the existing play equipment with an inclusive playground. This project includes accessible ramps and walkways along with pour-in-place safety surfacing and sidewalks. This project also constructs a roof and adds lighting and IT equipment to monitor street hockey games and tournaments in conjunction with NHL Carolina Hurricanes and community organizations.

name: Town Campus Stage
description: This project designs and builds a permanent stage at Town Campus in the arc lot in the grassy area which would be the final phase in transforming Town Campus into a fully functional event space. The stage design is round, so it mimics the arc lot shape and allows for stage view from all angles.
funding_source: Anticipated Grant Funding: $348,350, Anticipated Town Funding: $348,350

name: Wimberly Road Park
description: This project designs and develops nearly 50 acres with a 70,000+ square foot recreation center, maintenance facility, and yard. Given public input, preliminary project features include indoor staffed and programmed recreation space (gymnasium/multi-functional spaces/classrooms), trails, a passive open space, adaptive multi-use fields, sport courts, community gardens, and a park operation facility and yard to provide environmental education and conservation opportunities.
funding_source: General Fund / Capital Outlay, General Obligation Bonds

name: Depot Parking Lot Repurposing
description: Converting the Depot parking lot into a downtown gathering space is a "Top 10" priority project in the Downtown Plan. This includes a durable curbless environment, shaded areas, lighting, movable interactive furnishings, and space for community activities (farmer's market, splash pad, ice skating rink, seating and space to host various activities, etc.).
funding_source: General Fund / Capital Outlay, Installment Purchase / Capital Lease

name: Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment (EVSE) Infrastructure Development
description: This project installs the infrastructure required to power and utilize electric vehicle (EV) charging stations that will support electrifying the Town's fleet and fulfilling the Apex Sustainability Action Plan. This project follows the prioritized recommendations from the Electric Vehicle Suitability Assessment (EVSA) which evaluated which departments and facilities would be prime candidates for EV adoption if sufficient infrastructure were installed.

name: Fire Department Administration Building
description: The current Fire Department Administration Building occupies an old Apex Emergency Medical Services (EMS) station with 2,400 square feet of office space for 14 full-time employees, 2 limited-service employees, and Wake County EMS staff. This building is scheduled to be demolished during the NC 55 construction project in the coming years. This would use property at Fire Station 3 to address the space needs for offices, meetings, training, parking, and storage. The recent Space Needs Study recommended a 10,000 square foot facility.

name: Fire Station 3 Renovation and Addition
description: This project renovates Fire Station 3, so when Fire Station 1 closes, its engine company and crew can move to Fire Station 3. Currently, Fire Station 3 has insufficient kitchen, living room, bedroom, locker, and bathroom space for nine personnel per shift. This project includes needed renovations due to the station’s age (flooring, paint, fixtures, plumbing, etc.). In lieu of the separate storage building that was originally planned, this station renovation includes additional storage areas to accommodate the storage needs once Station 1 is closed and Fire Administration is relocated.

name: Hughes Street Mixed-Use Development
description: To prepare for housing and commercial development on this Town-owned site, street, water, and sewer infrastructure will be designed and built first. The project includes widening ~750 feet of Perry Rd to 35-foot width which includes shared lane markings and a 5-foot concrete sidewalk, widening ~750 feet of S. Hughes Street to 35-foot width which includes a 10-foot asphalt side path, and constructing ~3,000 feet of new on-site residential streets at 27-foot width with 5-foot sidewalks on both sides.

name: Public Safety Station 7 (Olive Farm Area)
description: This project constructs Public Safety Station 7 to serve the Olive Farm area and supports the Fire Department’s coverage standard (five-minute travel time for the first arriving fire apparatus 90% of the time). The Town’s Comprehensive Facilities Study recommends an 18,000+ square foot facility with three bays and enough room to accommodate two fire companies and a battalion chief.
funding_source: Installment Purchase / Capital Lease, General Fund / Capital Outlay

name: Townwide Solar Initiative
description: This project designs and constructs solar panels on twelve Town facilities over a two-year period. Solar projects are selected and prioritized based on the Town’s Solar Panel Assessment.
